robots so for example here's some bald eagles that can fight and stay in flight
and even Lex come less complex wing motions such as this paragon falcon and

these are birds that spend most of their lives in the air and they can even sleep while flying what they do is they can
finally tune their wing shapes in order to get the optimal shape for different
wind conditions so these large winged shape changes is something that we can
call or can be described as winged more thing and while winged morphing encompasses any large wing shape changes
my research focuses specifically on morphing wings that can extend and tuck
during gliding flight and birds can easily outmaneuver current flying aerial
robots and we can compare the performance of birds with other winged robots of similar size using a
five-point scale and so this is how Falcons compared to say a traditional quadrotor when we compare them for
robustness which is the ability to withstand collision birds are much better at being able to hit things and

to adapt to different wind conditions we can also compare them for flight speeds
glide ratio and also maneuverability which includes turn radiuses and turn

and when we compare them to similar robots they generally exceed the performance of robots and especially in
those top two categories the the metrics of robustness to collision as well as
the adaptability of wing shapes so by incorporating soft feathered morphing wings maybe we can help design robots
that can improve in these metrics so I use biological measurements in order to
understand how Birds accomplish these wing morphing maneuvers and then we can also apply that knowledge into designing
robots so in today's talk I'll talk about how I took biological measurements in bird
wings in order to design a morphing wing robot so let's start with the biology
and look at the pigeon wing anatomy so in the avian wing we have flight

wrist joint that lies between them and it's actuated with with fast-acting striated muscles so it's kind of
different than our arms birds have most of their feathers lie between their hand and their arm as opposed to having this
additional joint here and the primary feathers make up the hand wing so these are the ones that are further out and
then there are secondary feathers that make up most of the armed wing and this is what makes up the flying services of a bird and then all of these flight

angles are defined as the angle between the the feather and the what it makes
with the ulna so for the secondary feathers that's physically the angle between the bone and the feather since they attach but for the primary feathers
I project the axis or the feather as well as the ulna in order to get the effective angle between them and this is
just for measurement purposes or for like modeling purposes and in a
Windtunnel study of gliding pigeons died long ago by a scientist named penny quick free league lying pigeons have
been shown to glide in a wind tunnel and adapt naturally adapt different postures at different speeds and so what they
tend to do is they like to tuck in at higher wind speeds in order to reduce the wing profile drag and then they
extend their flights or they extend their wings more at slower speeds in order to create more lift and so this
ties back to that metric of adaptability of wing shapes to different wind conditions and so from this study we

wings shapes is is something that I wanted to investigate and if we can find that mechanism we can then apply it to
designing bio-inspired robots and we can help robots become more adaptable so to
get to robotic design I first measure the biological mechanism that's happening within the wing that enables
the pigeons to morph its wings and then from there I can create a model that can be translatable to the mechanics to
building a robot so in this experiment I used a motion capture system in order to
measure the locations of the bones within the wing as well as all the feathers so I've placed markers that are
tracked that are their marker clusters that are inserted directly into the bone which is why I use bird cadavers because
this is a pretty invasive invasive procedure and then I also place markers along every feather so these are all
twenty feathers flight feathers within the wing and what I do is I match the
motion of the wing to each of Penny quicks flight position flight positions and so here we see the wing fully
extended with the primary and secondary feathers in that like fully extended position we can also pose the feather
wing into the mid tax position as well as the fully tucked position and I can
track the motion of that but beyond just threes three poses we are also really interested in the continuous motion the
ability of the bird to flow seamlessly across all of these pose and adjust them instead of three discrete poses so I
animate the wing through its full range of motion all the way from flexion to extension
and I'm measuring the position of the bones and all the feathers as I do this and I take measurements of three
different individuals with 12 cycles each and from here we can calculate the motion of all the bones and the feathers
so from these measurements I can plot the wrist angle which is the input angle
on the x axis and then I have the measured feather angle along the y axis
and so plotted here is the average in the standard deviation for the feather
s10 which is the one closest to the body I track all 20 flight feathers within a wing but here I'll plot just a sampling
across the wings so here you see s 5 which is a middle secondary feather this
is p1 which is a wrist weight my feather within the wrist there's P 5 which is
the mid primary feather and then the farthest wingtip feather is P 10 and so
with these data we can show we can see that the relationship between the wrist angle and the feather angle is fairly
linear so I use a least squares fit to find a linear transfer function in order to mathematically map what the predicted
feather angle would be for a given wrist angle input and since each one of these
feathers is only a function of the wrist angle we can think about the entire wing
as a system that is under actuated so just by actuating the wrist angle we can control the motion of all the feathers
within oping we can also and another thing is that these are data from both flexion and
extension and so there's no hysteresis meaning that even when the bird opens and closes its wings the feathers move
kind of along the same path in both directions and we can plot the slopes of
this function of these functions and we can think about the slopes as a sensitivity to the wrist angle so
depending on how much the wrist angle moves will affect how much the feathers move so feathers closer to the body have
a slope of less than 1 so they don't move as much when the wrist angle moves which intuitively makes sense and the
distal tip feathers the ones furthest out have a really wide range of angles and they'll move a lot compared to what
their wrist angle so from these linear transfer functions
derived from the kinematic mod in the kinetic measurements we can now model the motion of under a created feathers
and I can use this linear model to create kind of a stick animation of the
wing and you can think of this as a rough prototype that lays out the the robotic mechanism of how to build an

the the purple lines representing the bone with Ola and the carpal metacarpus in this case I also include a sinker

that's a weave in between each of the feathers and to test this approximation
I created a model with linear elastic Springs between each flight feather and I assume that the flexion extension
happens only within the plane of the wing that the feathers are each attached to the bone via a frictionless pin joint
so they only have one degree of freedom rotating in that plane in the distance
that the spring attachment is estimated from biological measurements and
additionally that the the Springs all have a bit of pre tension even in that tucked flying position so that means
that they're still holding out their wings in the tucked position as opposed to completely relaxed when they're like walking around with their wings tucked in and now I
also assume that the furthest the furthest wingtip feather is rigidly
attached to the bone and when in in biology it really is the bone kind of fuses around that last feather and that
the the normalized force the force that it takes for the bird to stretch out and extend its wings is acting perpendicular
on to that last feather and then for the other boundary condition closer to the
body there's a lot of other smaller feathers here and so I model that and spring attachment as a moving one moving
as the average of the feathers next to it so I also assume that morphing is
quasi static so every wrist angle the feather the feathers aren't moving they're kind of static at each wrist
angle and so for the linear model I know the position of every single feather for a given wrist angle and I can also
assume that the sum of the moments around that feather is zero and so I can solve for the stiffness of each of the
springs because I know that the springs oppose each other within the feather and they sum to zero and so doing this
calculation so this is an example of one feather but if you do this as a system of equations across all twenty feathers
I can set up a matrix equation that allows me to solve for all the different spring stiffnesses K for each pose and I
can do this for each of the wrist angles and then predict what the average stiffness should be between two the
feathers so you can see this plotted here the bar chart shows the relative stiffness of the spring between each

and s1 and this makes sense because that's where the feathers separate a lot and you expect to have something that's

the wingtip feathers which also makes sense because you don't want the feathers separating when you have high
winds condition so you actually want the tip feathers to be much more stiff and so

maintain a continuous wing the feathers overlap and so in a way that the

services are important things to look at so since feathers are the building blocks of a bird wing I wanted to take a

their structure so here you can see a feather where you have the main central shaft which is the Reyes and then
there's these soft veins on either side and that's what creates the the aerodynamic surfaces but if you zoom in
you can see that zooming into this section you see that central central
Reyes again and then now you can see closer that the veins are actually made up of a bunch of barbs that are stitched

Center ramus and then they have branching barbules that branch off of

feathers are but the barbules themselves also have these branching structures
called cilia and now we're really into the micro scale and so in these

taking CT scans of hooks adjacent feathers and so this is a CT scan this
